children.name: old-fashioned
children.definition: old-fashioned clothes, styles, words etc are no longer considered modern or fashionable, although some people still wear them or still use them:
examples: ▪ I don’t wear that skirt now - it looks so old-fashioned.
▪ ‘Wireless’ is an old-fashioned word for radio.
▪ Albert was a tall, gangling man with long blond hair, like an old-fashioned rock star’s.

children.name: dated
children.definition: use this about clothes or styles that used to be fashionable, especially until recently, but now seem old-fashioned:

children.name: lỗi thời
examples: ▪ Just look at the hairstyles in this photo -- they’re so dated!
▪ The song was a big hit last year, but it’s already starting to sound dated.

children.name: be on the way out
children.definition: to be gradually becominglesspopularor common after having been very popular or fashionable:

children.name: đang lỗi thời, lỗi mốt
examples: ▪ It was said that coal was on the way out and would be replaced by nuclear energy.
▪ When I was in highschool disco was already on the way out.

children.name: old-fashioned
children.definition: old-fashioned opinions and ways of living were common in the past, but are not the way most people think and behave now:

children.name: lạc hậu
examples: ▪ In those days, people believed that divorce was morally wrong, but this now seems very old-fashioned.
▪ He has some very old-fashioned ideas about women.

children.name: outdated
children.definition: outdated opinions, methods, or systems are not suitable for modern times and need to be changed and made more modern:
examples: use in negative sentence
lạc hậu
▪ Outdated laws and regulations are failing to keep crime on the Internet in check.
▪ Outdated textbooks, decrepit buildings, overcrowded classrooms - the list of problems is long and growing.
▪ The image of the civil service as a male, middle class bastion is now outdated.

children.name: traditional
children.definition: traditional opinions, methods, or customs have existed for a long time, and have not been changed or affected by modern ideas:

children.name: truyền thống
examples: ▪ The local people still use traditional farming methods which have been used for hundreds of years.

children.name: ▪ the traditional idea that a woman’s place is in the home
examples: ▪ Tom went to a very traditional boys’ school.

children.name: lỗi thời, cổ lỗ sĩ
examples: outmoded belief/attitude/way of thinking etca way of thinking that was once popular but is not useful or suitable anymore:
▪ The views of many of the senior professors reflect outmoded concepts and ideas.
▪ The government’s outmoded attitudes are dragging the whole country back into the nineteenth century.

children.name: unfashionable
children.definition: abelief orattitudethat is unfashionable is no longer fashionable or popular:

children.name: lỗi mốt, lỗi thời
examples: ▪ Smoking has become very unfashionable in the last ten years.

children.name: it is unfashionable to do something
examples: ▪ It’s unfashionable these days to say you want to get married and give up your job, isn’t it?

children.name: old-fashioned
children.definition: old-fashioned machines and equipment have a design that is no longer modern:

children.name: lỗi thời
examples: ▪ He rides one of those old-fashioned bikes with high handlebars.
▪ A lot of the machines at the factory are very old-fashioned.
▪ Old-fashioned ceiling fans have been making a comeback as a cheap and reliable alternative to air conditioning.

children.name: outdated
children.definition: use this about machines or equipment that use old-fashioned designs, and should be replaced with more modern ones:

children.name: lỗi thời
examples: ▪ It is hard to run a business with outdated equipment.

children.name: ▪ a rebel army, equipped only with outdated Russian weapons
obsolete
children.definition: use this about machines and equipment that are no longer being produced, and that seem old-fashioned because newer machines have been invented which can do the job much better:
examples: lỗi thời ( không sản xuất nữa )
▪ The old 5¼ inch floppy disks are now obsolete.
make something obsolete
▪ a new type of ‘Network Computer’, which could make existing PCs obsolete within five years

children.name: antiquated
children.definition: very old and old-fashioned and no longer suitable for modern needs:

children.name: cổ, ko hợp thời
examples: ▪ My mother’s antiquated vacuum cleaner still works, believe it or not.
▪ Hospitals suffer from inadequate facilities, antiquated equipment and shortages of medical supplies.

children.name: out of date
children.definition: out-of-date/  use this about books, maps etc that do not contain the most recent information, or about information that is no longer right because the facts have changed:
examples: lỗi thời,
▪ The map we had with us was completely out of date.

children.name: be stuck in a time-warp
children.definition: be stuck/caught in a time-warp  if a place is stuck in a time-warp, it has not changed and seems the same as it was many years ago:

children.name: bất chấp thời gian
examples: ▪ That restaurant is still stuck in some kind of late-seventies time-warp.
▪ The country had little contact with the outside world, and remained caught in something of a time-warp.

children.name: old-fashioned
examples: ▪ Mr Griffiths is a real old-fashioned teacher who still believes that learning lessons by heart is the best method.
▪ My Dad was very old-fashioned and didn’t approve of me going to nightclubs with my friends.

children.name: be living in the past
children.definition: to think and behave as if life is still like it was when you were young, especially because you do not like the modern world:
examples: ▪ You’ve got to get over it, honey - you’ve got to stop living in the past.
▪ Critics say Buchanan is living in the past, and remind him that the 1950s was a time when women were shackled to the kitchen, and African-Americans held back by discrimination.

children.name: behind the times
children.definition: apersonororganizationwho is behind the times, is old-fashioned because they have not changed while the world around them has changed:

children.name: cổ hủ
examples: ▪ People in these parts tend to be way behind the times when it comes to issues such as women’s rights.
▪ Once the giants of British retailing, they are now seen as being behind the times.

children.name: straitlaced/straightlaced
children.definition: having a very strong, old-fashioned attitude tomoralbehaviour:

children.name: khắt khe câu lệ, khổ hạnh
examples: ▪ My aunt’s very straitlaced - she’d be shocked if you mentioned sex.
▪ They lost touch with Hermine after she married a very straightlaced Lutheran minister, and disappeared from the social scene.

children.name: fuddy duddy
children.definition: someone who you think is old-fashioned and boring because they disapprove of new ideas and are unwilling to change their attitudes:
examples: fuddy-duddy[adjective]
▪ She has some rather fuddy-duddy ideas about what is proper music.

children.name: hủ lậu
examples: ▪ Don’t be such a fuddy duddy!
▪ The election broadcast made the President look like a fuddy duddy with ridiculously old-fashioned ideas.

children.name: old fogey
children.definition: someone, usually an old person, who you disapprove of because they prefer old-fashioned ideas and ways of doing things to modern ones:

children.name: kẻ cổ hủ
examples: ▪ The old fogies all sit together and talk about the old days.
▪ This country is being run by a bunch of old fogies -- we need some fresh blood, people with initiative.

children.name: old guard
children.definition: a group of people with old-fashioned opinions, who have been in an organization or society for a long time and oppose anyone who wants to change things:

children.name: vệ binh lão thành
examples: ▪ Inevitably, the revolution is affecting the old guard much more than the rest of us.
▪ The party’s old guard have their own candidate for leader.

children.name: traditionalist
children.definition: a person who believes that theold waysof doing things are the best, and who does not like modern methods or ideas:

children.name: người nệ cổ, người theo chủ nghĩa truyền thống
examples: ▪ I’m something of a traditionalist myself, I’d much rather use pen and paper than a word-processor.
▪ There are still many traditionalists in the church who strongly oppose the idea of women priests.

children.name: medieval
children.definition: extremely old-fashioned and thereforeannoying:

children.name: lạc hậu
examples: ▪ The plumbing in this house is medieval!

children.name: positively medievalvery medieval : cực kì lạc hậu
examples: ▪ This so-called accounting system is positively medieval.

children.name: out of the ark
children.definition: Britishinformalextremely old-fashioned:
examples: ▪ Their washing machine looks like it came out of the ark.
▪ Her views on social policy are embarrassing -- really out of the ark.

children.name: dinosaur
children.definition: asystem, organization etcthat is very old-fashioned and large and cannot continue to exist in the modern world:

children.name: khủng long
examples: ▪ The Health Service has become a dinosaur. It needs radical reform if it is to survive.
▪ The line-up includes a number of rock-n-roll dinosaurs who should have hung up their guitars long ago.

children.name: anachronism
children.definition: something such as anorganizationorcustomthat belongs to a time in the past, and therefore appears very strange in the modern world:
examples: anachronistic/əˌnækrəˈnɪstɪk◂/ [adjective]
▪ Many people believe that the role of the Royal Family in Britain is anachronistic.

children.name: (tổ chức, phong tục) lỗi thời
examples: ▪ The harvest festival celebrations in the town are an anachronism since almost everyone who lives there nowadays works in an office.

children.name: archaic
children.definition: use this aboutsomethingthat was used a long time ago but which is now considered too old-fashioned andneedsreplacing:

children.name: cổ xưa
examples: ▪ The text was full of archaic spellings.
▪ The laws that decide who owns items discovered on an archeological exploration are ridiculously archaic.

children.name: Dickensian
children.definition: buildings, conditions etc that are Dickensian areextremelyold-fashioned and below acceptable standards, for example because they are dangerous or unhealthy:

children.name: ▪ They were living in a Dickensian apartment block without proper heating or running water.positively Dickensian
examples: ▪ The working conditions in the factory were positively Dickensian.

children.name: the dark ages
children.definition: use this to talk about a society, system, or way of thinking that is extremely old-fashioned, especially in its social attitudes:

children.name: thời tối cổ
examples: ▪ Huge amounts of aid will be needed if this society is ever to drag itself out of the dark ages.
▪ My brother still doesn’t like the idea of having a woman boss - he’s stuck in the dark ages!

children.name: old-fashioned
children.definition: old-fashioned in a way thatremindsyou ofnicethingsin the past:
examples: cổ , không hợp thời trang
▪ The town has a lovely old-fashioned charm about it.
▪ He was a nice, old-fashioned gentleman who would hold open the door for you or offer to carry your bags.good old-fashioned
▪ good old-fashioned home cooking

children.name: quaint
children.definition: old-fashioned and unusual, butattractiveandinteresting- use this about smallbuildingsorplaces, or aboutcustomsandbeliefs:

children.name: cổ
examples: ▪ We stayed in a quaint little fishing village in Cornwall.

children.name: ▪ quaint country cottages
examples: ▪ Stigler scoffed at the quaint idea of university as a place where a professor and a small group of students can sit in a study and discuss great thoughts.
